awd_titl_txt: Quantum Entanglement and Dynamics in Lattice Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports fundamental theoretical research and education aimed at advancing our grasp of quantum aspects of condensed matter theory at low dimensions. The major fundamental difficulty in describing and theoretically representing quantum many-body systems is the vast number of parameters required. The number of such parameters increases exponentially with the number of constituents of a system, and thus quickly becomes intractable for numerical computations, even for small quantum systems. Thus, efficient descriptions of quantum systems are of fundamental importance to our understanding of complex systems and of their applications. 

In this project, the PI will study a new representation for certain quantum systems that is exact and efficient. Another front of the research is the development of models of quantum systems that efficiently describe their dynamics, for example quantum detectors under the influence of measurements and external disturbances. The detailed understanding of such dynamics may find a crucial role in the development of a host of new experimental diagnostic tools, and of platforms for quantum computing.

The project will require the use and development of new theoretical tools in the arsenal of theoretical physics of many-body quantum states. Also, in tandem with the research, the project will involve the training of graduate students in cutting-edge methods of theoretical physics, which are vital for a scientific career but also form a core of ideas that often find new uses in industry.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education to advance our grasp of quantum aspects of condensed matter theory at low dimensions through the study of entanglement, dynamics, and fluctuations in many-body states. There are three main topics of study:

The first topic is a study of the interplay of locality and entanglement and its relation to variational methods like tensor network states. The PI will focus on recently discovered Hamiltonians that exhibit highly entangled ground states and new phase transitions, and unusual dynamical scaling properties.

The second topic will deal with a set of quantum nonequilibrium problems, a topic of current interest due to advancement in theory and experiment. Theory lags significantly behind experimental abilities primarily due to the inability to effectively simulate many-body dynamics. Via a numerical framework based on closed hierarchies of equations, the PI will study nonequilibrium current generation, effects of the motion of detectors and sources in a Fermi sea, quantum wakes, and role of the interplay between disorder and measurements.

In a third topic, the PI will investigate a new class of boson impurity models that can be mapped into certain photonic cluster states, with particular emphasis on relating these states to ground states of interesting physical disordered systems that may ultimately be amenable to quantum simulation.

The methods and approaches employed and developed will allow for a fruitful exchange of ideas between researchers in condensed matter, quantum information, high-energy physics, and in mathematics. Nonequilibrium quantum physics plays a role in a wide swath of applications from fundamental physics understanding to the development of devices.  Finally, an essential component of the project is that it will provide opportunities for the training of new researchers, whose development as scientists is a vital goal of the proposed activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our ability to control quantum mechanical many-body systems, manipulate them, and probe them grows rapidly, with numerous applications to quantum simulation, metrology, and quantum information. At the heart of many of these lies the role of uniquely quantum mechanical features, such as the role of measurement and the non-classical correlations we call entanglement. 
In this project, we looked for new ways to describe and analyze many-body entangled states and to describe interesting non-equilibrium systems that may include periodic driving, measurements and more.

The outcomes of the projects are exciting in all of the above situations. Amongst the results supported by the funding: Describing the motion of a quantum detector interacting with a quantum gas and the notion of a quantum wake (see "Quantum wakes in lattice fermions", M Wampler, P Schauss, EB Kolomeisky, I Klich Phys. Rev. Res. 3 (3), 033112 (2021)), a design of a of quantum measurements protocol that leads to the development of chiral edge transport of charge ("Stirring by staring: Measurement-induced chirality", M Wampler, BJJ Khor, G Refael, I Klich Phys. Rev. X 12 (3), 031031 (2022)): when a particle is injected into this repeatedly measured sample its behavior depends crucially on the location. If it is injected in the bulk it diffuses without a preferred direction; however, when the particle is on the edge of the sample, it has a well-defined probability to be transported along the edge. In a similar vein we suggested novel non-equilibrium interacting 2D systems that can be tuned to be classical automata, time crystals and more ("Arrested development and fragmentation in strongly-interacting Floquet systems" M Wampler, I Klich, SciPost Phys.14 (6), 145 (2023) and  "Fragmentation and prethermal dynamical phases in disordered strongly interacting Floquet systems", M Wampler, I Klich Phys. Rev. B 108 (10), 104315 (2023))

We have described how interesting quantum mechanical spin systems may be described in terms of a non-unitary hierarchical tensor network ("Exact holographic tensor networks for the Motzkin spin chain", RN Alexander, G Evenbly, I Klich Quantum 5, 546 (2021)), and analyzed the emergent holographic description of a Lifshitz space time  ("Emergent geometry and path integral optimization for a Lifshitz action", A Ahmadain, I Klich Phys. Rev. D 103 (10), 105013 (2021)).

In other work we explored ideas for building highly entangled cluster states of photons ("Spatiotemporal graph states from a single optical parametric oscillator."  R Yang, J Zhang, I Klich, C Gonz?lez-Arciniegas, O Pfister Phys. Rev. A 101 (4), 043832 13, (2020)) as well as proposed classes of models with ground states hiding abnormally large amounts of entanglement as characterized by entanglement entropy ("Coupled Fredkin and Motzkin chains from quantum six-and nineteen-vertex models", Z Zhang, I Klich, SciPost Phys. 15 (2), 044, (2023) and "Quantum colored lozenge tiling and entanglement phase transition" Z Zhang, I Klich preprint arXiv:2210.01098 (2022)), providing a high dimensional generalization to previous works. 

Beyond the interest and importance of the results themselves, the project also crucially supported research and training of students, two of whom have graduated with a PhD in physics based on the this research and advanced to lucrative postdoctoral positions.
